Mallesh Data curation Formal analysis a b N. Lingaiah Funding acquisition Project administration Supervision Writing – review & editing a b ⁎ a Department of Catalysis & Fine Chemicals, CSIR-Indian Institute of Chemical Technology, Hyderabad 500007, Telangana, India Department of Catalysis & Fine Chemicals CSIR-Indian Institute of Chemical Technology Hyderabad Telangana 500007 India aDepartment of Catalysis & Fine Chemicals, CSIR-Indian Institute of Chemical Technology, Hyderabad 500007, Telangana, India b CSIR-Academy of Scientific and Innovative Research (CSIR-AcSIR), Ghaziabad 201002, India CSIR-Academy of Scientific and Innovative Research (CSIR-AcSIR) Ghaziabad 201002 India bCSIR-Academy of Scientific and Innovative Research (CSIR-AcSIR), Ghaziabad 201002, India ⁎ Corresponding author. o-Chlorotoluene (o-CT) ammoxidation to prepare o-chlorobenzonitrile (o-CBN) was investigated on Al2O3-ZrO2 supported V2O5 catalysts in the temperature range of 360 to 420 °C. A set of vanadium oxide supported on mixed oxides with varying its loadings were prepared by wet impregnation method. The catalysts surface and structural characteristics were derived from BET-surface area, X-ray diffraction, FT-infrared, temperature programmed reduction, temperature programmed desorption of ammonia and UV–Vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy. The characterization results revealed that vanadium species were well dispersed and strongly interacted with mixed oxide support. The ammoxidation activity was depended on V2O5 content and its nature of surface species existing in the catalyst. The catalyst with 10 wt% of V2O5 on Al2O3-ZrO2 showed high ammoxidation activity with 100% selectivity to o-CBN. Moreover, the catalyst showed consistent activity during time on stream study. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ammoxidation o-Chlorotoluene o-Chlorobenzonitrile Vanadia Alumina-Zirconia 1 Introduction Ammoxidation has been emerging as a clean, economically efficient and environmentally friendly route for the production of nitriles. The advantage of ammoxidation to produce nitriles is that it avoids the formation of toxic organic residues unlike conventional preparation method. The conventional methods for the preparation of aromatic nitriles are (i) Rosenmund – von Braun reaction of aryl halides using stoichiometric amounts of copper(I) cyanide (ii) Diazotization of anilines and subsequent Sandmeyer reaction. Transition-metal catalysed cyanation of aromatic halides, aromatic cyanation using nano-metallic cyano groups, dehydration of aryl amides or oximes and the oxidative dehydration of benzylic amines or alcohols with ammonia are the methods used for the synthesis of aromatic nitriles [1-4]. Ammoxidation refers to the direct conversion of methyl to nitriles using ammonia and molecular oxygen [5,6]. Ammoxidation ofo-chlorotoluene (o-CT) to o-chlorobenzonitrile (o-CBN) is of particular interest in recent years because the product o-CBN is used as a key starting compound for the production of o-chlorobenzylamine, used as antifolate, blood stream disorder disease remedy, analgesic, anticoagulant, antitumor and antihypertensive. o-CBN is also used in the production of industrially important azo dyes [7,8]. Nitriles are valued intermediates for synthesis of dyestuffs, pesticides and pharmaceuticals [9-13]. However, it is still a very difficult and challenging subject to industrialize the ammoxidation process. The important factor in the advance of ammoxidation reaction lies in the development of highly efficient catalysts [14]. Vanadium based catalysts were used for vapour phase ammoxidation of methyl aromatics (e.g. toluene, xylenes, and halogen containing toluene) and hetero aromatics (e.g. picolines, methyl pyrazine) to their respective nitriles [15-18]. The oxides containing vanadium are efficient catalysts for ammoxidation reaction due to its redox property [19,20]. Ammoxidation reaction follows redox mechanism on vanadium-based catalysts. Different catalytic system such as vanadium phosphorous oxides (VPO), V-Ti oxides, V-W oxides, V-Mo oxides, vanadium supported on oxides and mixed oxide are widely studied for ammoxidation of methyl aromatic compounds [12, 10, 21], methanol oxidation, oxidative dehydrogenation of alkanes and oxidation of hydrocarbons [22-24]. Ammoxidation of o-CT is also carried on vanadium-based catalysts [25]. Mixed oxide supported catalysts showed better catalytic properties than supported on mono oxide catalysts [26, 27]. The combination of mixed oxides like Al2O3-ZrO2 gives improved mechanical strength, resulting in better resistance to attrition [28, 29]. The importance of Al2O3-ZrO2 as a catalyst support provide moderate surface area, medium acidity and higher thermal stability [30]. Compared to simple toluene ammoxidation, o-CT ammoxidation activity is low and its activity varies with change in the morphology of vanadia. It is thought to use catalyst with low vanadia content, contain to have mono dispersed vanadia species which may enhance the ammoxidation activity of o-CT relatively at moderate reaction temperature. It is also anticipated that by using mixed oxides as support to modify the surface and structural features of vanadium species. In the present work, we report a set of V2O5 supported on Al2O3-ZrO2 mixed oxide catalysts used for the synthesis of o-CBN by vapour phase ammoxidation of o-CT. The catalysts were prepared with varying amounts of V2O5 on Al2O3-ZrO2. The nature of interaction between V2O5 and Al2O3-ZrO2 support and the kind of surface species were explored to correlate activity and selectivity of the catalysts. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Preparation of catalysts Analytical grade chemicals were used without any purification. The chemicals ammonia solution, aluminium nitrate, oxalic acid, o-chlorotoluene were procured from SD Chemicals India and ammonium metavanadate, zirconyl oxynitrate obtained from Sigma-Aldrich. Al2O3-ZrO2 (1:1 molar ratio) support was synthesized using co-precipitation approach [31]. In this method 10% ammonia solution was added drop wise to quantitatively mixed aqueous solutions of aluminium nitrate (0.39 M) and zirconyl oxy nitrate (0.16 M) under continuous stirring until the pH value reached 8. Thus obtained precipitate was filtered with frequent washing using distilled water. The wet cake was oven dried at 120 °C for 12 h and followed by calcination at 500 °C for 6 h. The prepared support was designated as Al-Zr. A series of V2O5 supported on Al2O3-ZrO2 catalysts with vanadia content ranging from 5 to 15 wt% were synthesized by wet impregnation technique [10]. The requisite amount of ammonia metavanadate dissolved in aqueous solution containing oxalic acid was added to the support with stirring. The amount of oxalic acid is 2 moles for every one mole of vanadia precursor. The wet samples are kept on hot plate at 80 °C to drive off water present in the catalyst mass. The catalysts were oven dried for 12 h at 100 °C followed by calcination at 450 °C for 4 h. 2.2 Characterization of the catalysts BELSorb ΙΙ Instrument, Japan was utilized to determine BET surface area of the catalysts by N2 adsorption-desorption method at liquid N2 temperature. Before measurement the catalysts were out-gassed for 2 h at 200 °C. X-ray diffraction (XRD) of the samples were determined on a Rigaku Miniflex (Regaku corporation, Japan) X-ray diffractometer containing Ni filtered Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.5406A°). FT-IR spectra were obtained on a Biorad-Excalibur series spectrometer (USA) using KBr disc method. About 0.1 g catalyst sample is mixed with 0.5 g of KBr and grinded finely before making pellet for measurements. FT-IR spectra of the samples were recorded in the range from 600 to 4000 cm−1. BELCAT-ΙΙ (Japan) equipment was used for temperature programmed reduction (TPR) analysis. The samples were preheated with Ar gas flow for about 2 h at 250 °C to eliminate weakly adsorbed water. TPR analysis was conducted with 5% H2/Ar mixture gas flow with a flow rate of 30 ml min−1 by increasing the temperature with a temperature ramp of 10 C min−1. The hydrogen consumption was estimated by thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) obtained in UV-Visible region (200–800 nm) using a GBC Cintra 10E UV- Visible spectrometer using a split width of 1.5 nm and a scan speed of 400 nm per minute. Pellets were made by taking 15 mg of the catalyst sample and dried KBr. Temperature programmed desorption of ammonia (TPD-NH3) method was adopted to measure acidity of the catalysts. BELCAT-ΙΙ equipment was used for TPD analysis. About 50 mg of catalyst was taken in a sample tube and pre-heated at 100 °C for 1 h in helium flow to remove any adsorbed species on the surface of the catalyst. The catalyst was exposed to 10% NH3 at 100°C for 1 h. The physisorbed NH3 was flushed off with He gas flow at the same temperature. The TPD analysis was conducted in the temperature range from 100 to 600 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The desorbed ammonia gas was measured by TCD. 2.3 Reaction procedure Vapour phase ammoxidation of o-CT to o-CBN was conducted at atmospheric pressure in a continuous-down flow fixed bed reactor. The schematic diagram of the reactor is displayed in Fig 1 . The temperature of the reaction was monitored with the help of thermocouple placed inside the catalyst bed. In a standard experiment, about 3 g of the catalyst diluted with same amount of quartz beads, was loaded into the centre of the reactor. Prior to reaction test, the catalyst was treated at 450 °C with H2 gas for 2 h. Then the reactor was brought to the required reaction temperature and the reactants NH3, air and o-CT were passed into the reactor. The o-CT was fed into the reactor with a metering pump (B. Braun, Germany) at a flow rate of 3 ml/h. The flow rates of NH3 and air were controlled with the help of mass flow controllers. The molar ratio of o-CT: NH3: Air = 1:4:10 was maintained. Experiments were carried out at different temperatures varying from 360 oC to 440 oC . After attaining the study state condition, the products coming out of the reaction were collected in a cold trap. This reaction product was analysed using a gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with flame ionized detector (FID), by separating the products on ZB-5 capillary column. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 BET surface area BET surface area of V2O5/Al-Zr catalysts are presented in Table 1 . The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms are presented in Fig 2 . The support Al-Zr surface area was 215 m2 g−1 . The addition of 5 wt% vanadia decreased the surface area of support Al-Zr from 215 to 159 m2 g−1. A substantial fall in the surface area was noticed with enhancement of vanadia content, which can be referred to the blocking of pores of support by V2O5 species [25,32]. In general, the solid-state reaction between support and dispersed V2O5 might led to the observed decrease in the catalysts surface area [33,34]. 3.2 XRD analysis XRD patterns of the catalysts with various loadings of vanadium oxide supported on Al-Zr and calcined at 450 °C are shown in Fig. 3 . The diffraction peaks noticed at 2θ of 30.4°, 50.9° and 60.4° are attributed to ZrO2 tetragonal phase [35]. The broad diffraction peaks at 2θ = 35.4°, 46° and 66.6° were related to Al2O3 [6]. When V2O5 content exceeded 10 wt%, the diffraction peaks related to ZrO2 appeared and this peaks intensity increased with further enhancement in vanadia content. The presence of high content of metal oxides like V2O5 or WO3 had strong interaction with zirconia and led to the formation of selective tetragonal zirconia phase [36]. The presence of high amount of vanadia might have strong interaction with support and leading to form crystalline zirconia. Diffraction patterns concerned to V2O5 phase are not present in the catalysts. This directly indicate that well dispersed V2O5 was present on Al-Zr support probably in the form of VO4 monomeric units and V-O-V two dimensional structures [37]. 3.3 Fourier transform-IR spectra of the catalysts The catalysts FT-IR spectra are presented in Fig. 4 . The band at 1000 cm−1 was ascribed to stretching mode of V=O bonds (terminal oxygen) [38,39]. The broad band observed around 3434 cm−1 is due to O-H stretching vibrations of water molecule. The bending vibration of O-H group of adsorbed water was appeared at 1648 cm−1 [40,41]. The bands appear at 2356 cm−1 and 2116 cm−1 can be related to the adsorption of CO2 (O=C=O) linear species and CO vibrations respectively [42]. The appearance of small band at 1360 cm−1 can be attributed to ammonia which might be originated during the preparation [43]. These absorption bands intensity became less with the increase in vanadia loading. This indicates a possible interaction between vanadia and support. The V2O5 bands were not detected below 1000 cm−1. These results confirm that V2O5 species are in well dispersed state. Reported results indicate at lower loadings of V2O5 exist as amorphous, whereas at higher loadings it presents as crystalline and amorphous V2O5 or AlVO4 in crystalline phase [44]. These bands were not observed in the present study might be due to the highly dispersed state of V2O5. XRD results are in support of these observations. 3.4 TPR results TPR was used to investigate the reducibility of vanadium deposited on the support. TPR profiles of the catalysts are compiled in Fig. 5 . The vanadium present on the support may exist in three different forms namely monovanadate, polyvanadate and crystalline phase. When the vanadium loading is low it mostly exists as monovanadate. Polyvanadate presents on the support when vanadium content is moderately high. When the vanadium loading is exceeds the monolayer coverage then the crystalline phase is formed. The monovanadate reducibility is comparable to that of polyvanadate. There was only one reduction peak observed on Al-Zr supported samples with vanadia loadings of 5–15 wt% [45, 46]. The mono reduction peak noticed in the catalysts is in well agreement with the reports of previous work [47–51]. The reduction peak is in the temperature range of 450–610 °C with Tmax at 560 °C for 5% V2O5/Al-Zr catalyst related to the reduction of polymeric vanadium species (i.e. V+5 to V+4) present in the catalyst [43]. With increasing vanadia loading, Tmax shifted to higher temperature with a greater intensity of the peak. The enhanced intensity with high temperature shift suggests the presence of polymeric vanadia species. The shift in temperature also indicates an intense interaction between polymeric vanadia species with support. The reduction peaks slightly shifted to lower temperature for the catalyst with high V2O5 content. This is might be due to presence of bulk V2O5 crystalline phase which are reduced early than interacted polymeric vanadia species. 3.5 UV–Vis diffuse reflectance spectra UV–Vis DRS of the V2O5/Al-Zr catalysts are presented in Fig. 6 . The energy of oxygen to metal charge transfer absorption band, related with the minimum diffuse reflectance, is majorly influenced by the number of oxygen ligands associated with the central vanadium ion. Thus, it can be used to determine the structure and type of vanadium species [52,53]. All the catalysts reveal two charge transfer absorption bands at 210 and 300 nm. The band at 210 nm could be assigned to isolated vanadia sites in tetrahedral co-ordination and later band at 300 nm related to polymeric V-O-V species [54]. In the present catalysts no absorption bands were found above 450 nm in the spectrum, implying that the d-d transition of V+4 and V+3 ions were absent [55,56]. Vanadia spread on support presents a broad range of VOx structure and proposed that V2O5 exists as isolated or monomeric vanadia species with tetrahedral co-ordination at lower absorption band while polymeric vanadia species are noticed at high absorption band due to progressive condensation of the monomeric species [50,57]. 3.6 Temperature programmed desorption of NH3 Fig. 7 depicts the NH3-TPD pattern of the catalysts and it is used to estimate acidic characteristics of the catalysts. The distribution of acidic sites along with total acidity of the catalysts are presented in Table 1. The strength of acid site distribution noticed from NH3-TPD studies were divided into three types. Low temperature region (100–250 °C) relevant to weak acidic sites, desorption temperature in the range of 250–450 °C associated to moderate acidic sites and desorption peak above 450 °C was related with strong acidic sites [10]. As shown in Fig. 7 the catalysts exhibited three desorption peaks. However, in case of 5 and 10 wt% vanadia content two desorption peaks, which are related to weak and moderate acidic sites as indicated in figure are predominant and a low intense desorption at high temperature was notice for these catalysts. The low temperature desorption peak with a Tmax of 190 °C is ascribed to acidic sites associated to isolated vanadia species. Another desorption peak noticed above 350 °C is assign to the Bronsted acidity originating from highly dispersed/polymeric vanadia species [58–60]. 3.7 Catalytic activity The catalytic activity of the V2O5/Al-Zr catalysts were screened for ammoxidation of o-CT at atmospheric pressure and the results are depicted in Fig. 8 . Ammoxidation of o-CT resulted in the formation of o-CBN as desired product and other possible side products are benzonitrile, chlorobenzene and toluene. In the present study all the catalysts selectively yielded the product o-CBN only. There is no other by products observed over these catalysts. The variation in the catalytic activity was observed with change in the V2O5 loading in the catalysts. The catalyst with low loading of V2O5 up to 7.5 wt%, showed only 58.4% conversion. When the loading increased to 10 wt% the conversion increased up to 65%. A further increase to V2O5 content led to decrease in conversion and it reached a value of 47%. The maximum catalytic activity was observed for 10 wt% V2O5/Al-Zr catalyst. The activity profiles of the catalysts can be explained based on their surface structure features. The reported literature suggests that metal vanadates are selective and active catalysts for ammoxidation reactions [61]. Haribabu et al. recommended that isolated, polymeric vanadia species and alumina vanadates present in catalysts were responsible for the selectivity of o-CBN [43]. Similarly, Dhachapally et al. reported that the presence of vanadia polymeric species are important for selective synthesis of 2-cyanopyrazine from 2-methylpyrazine ammoxidation [62]. In present study, the catalysts contains mainly species of isolated and polymeric vanadia. The XRD result suggests that V2O5 was well dispersed state in the present catalytic system and having strong interactions with the support. The studies of TPR and UV–Vis DRS revealed that isolated surface vanadia and polymeric vanadia species were present for the catalysts with V2O5 content up to 10 wt%. The catalyst with 10 wt% V2O5/Al-Zr showed high activity might be related to presence of vanadia species in isolated and polymeric form. The decrease in activity for high V2O5 containing catalysts might be due to the existence of V2O5 in microcrystalline form and the presence of crystalline Al2O3 and ZrO2 phases are noticed from XRD. In these V+5 was present in tetrahedral co-ordination. NH3-TPD studies revealed that, there is a continuous decrease in the acidity of the catalysts due to the less presence of surface OH groups, which are participated in the polymerisation, led to the formation of crystalline V2O5. These results guide us that isolated and polymeric vanadia species having tetrahedral co-ordination are active for ammoxidation. In ammoxidation reaction catalyst acidity also plays an influential role by enriching the adsorption capability of the reactant NH3. 3.8 Effect of reaction temperature Table 2 displays the significance of reaction temperature on ammoxidation activity over the V2O5/Al-Zr catalyst. The reaction performed in the temperature range of 360 to 440 °C. The conversion of o-CT increased with increase in temperature from 360 to 440 °C for all the catalysts. When the temperature increased to 440 °C a marginal decrease in selectivity was observed for all the catalysts. The conversion of o-CT was maximum with a yield of 65% at 420 °C. Generally, ammoxidation activity over V2O5 based catalysts showed high conversion above 420 °C to 440 °C. The mass balance analysis was carried for the reactions performed at different temperatures. The reaction product mixture analysis suggests the formation of only o-CBN with 100% selectivity. No other products were detected for the reaction carried up to 420 °C. The amount of carbon oxides were estimated by gas chromatography equipped with thermal conductivity detector. The formation of 1% COX was noticed along with about 3% of benzonitrile when the reaction was performed at 440 °C. 3.9 Effect of gas hourly space velocity Fig. 9 shows the conversion of o-CT over 10 wt%V2O5/Al-Zr catalyst under different gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) at a reaction temperature of 420 °C. As can be seen, the o-CT conversion gradually decreased from 65 to 32% by increasing GHSV from 1400 to 2100 h−1. This occurs since the higher GHSV results in a lower residence time, which subsequently led to lower conversion. The important aspect of the present catalyst is that at different GHSV also the selectivity is not altered. This signifies the selective nature of the catalyst. 3.10 Comparison of the present catalyst with other catalysts The present active 10 wt%V2O5/Al-Zr catalyst is compared with other reported catalysts and the details about comparative activity are displayed in Table 3 . The V2O5/ Al2O3 catalyst showed about 41% conversion at 420 °C at high mole ratio of air compared to present catalyst. Martin et.al. reported about 40% yield of o-CBN during the ammoxidation of o-CT over VPO catalysts [7]. Metal oxide promoted V2O5/ Al2O3 catalysts are also showed moderate yields of 50–62% at relatively high air molar ratio [10]. In another study the ammoxidation of o-CT ammoxidation carried over 10 and 20 wt%V2O5 supported on Al2O3 and reported 28% and 76% yield of o-CBN [25]. However, these catalysts showed low selectivity (62–79%) with high mole ratios of NH3 and air. The present catalysts exhibited high activity than the earlier reported catalysts with low mole ratios of 4:10 of NH3 and air respectively. 4 Time on stream studies Time on stream analysis was tested over 10 wt% V2O5/Al-Zr catalyst to understand stability of the catalyst and the results are displayed in Fig. 10 . The reactions were carried in the time intervals of 1 to 24 h. The catalyst showed almost constant activity during 24 h of time on stream analysis. Both conversion and selectivity were constant during the entire period of reaction. The spent catalyst was characterised by XRD to see any changes in the surface and structural features. Fig. 11 shows the XRD profile of the fresh and spent 10 wt%V2O5/Al-Zr catalysts. There are some changes in the XRD pattern indicating that crystalline phases are formed after 24 h reaction. The used catalysts was also characterized by Raman spectroscopy to see any formation of coke. The analysis suggests that there was no Raman bands related to coke for the used catalyst. From the above results we can conclude that this catalyst composition is more resistant towards deactivation by coke formation. 5 Conclusion Al2O3-ZrO2 based mixed oxides are interesting support to disperse of vanadium oxide for ammoxidation reaction. V2O5 dispersed Al2O3-ZrO2 catalysts are selective and active for ammoxidation of o-CT to yield o-CBN. The ammoxidation activity depends on the content of V2O5 on the support. The results indicate that support plays an important role in dispersion of V2O5. The presence of well dispersed vanadium in the form of isolated and polymeric tetrahedral species are responsible for ammoxidation activity. The catalyst with 10 wt% V2O5 on Al2O3-ZrO2 is most active catalyst at low ammonia and air molar ratios compared to other catalysts. A maximum conversion of o-CT was 65% with 100% selectivity to o-CBN was attained. The present catalyst is highly stable as it showed consistent activity during time on stream analysis. coredata.dc:description: o-Chlorotoluene (o-CT) ammoxidation to prepare o-chlorobenzonitrile (o-CBN) was investigated on Al2O3-ZrO2 supported V2O5 catalysts in the temperature range of 360 to 420 °C. A set of vanadium oxide supported on mixed oxides with varying its loadings were prepared by wet impregnation method. The catalysts surface and structural characteristics were derived from BET-surface area, X-ray diffraction, FT-infrared, temperature programmed reduction, temperature programmed desorption of ammonia and UV–Vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy. The characterization results revealed that vanadium species were well dispersed and strongly interacted with mixed oxide support. The ammoxidation activity was depended on V2O5 content and its nature of surface species existing in the catalyst. The catalyst with 10 wt% of V2O5 on Al2O3-ZrO2 showed high ammoxidation activity with 100% selectivity to o-CBN. Moreover, the catalyst showed consistent activity during time on stream study.
coredata.dc:title: Understanding the role of Al2O3-ZrO2 mixed oxides as support for vanadium catalysts for the selective ammoxidation of o-chlorotoluene to o-chlorobenzonitrile
